awd_titl_txt: Measurements and Models of Cell Nuclear Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells are subject to numerous types of mechanical stress, from forces exerted on the skin to fluid shear within blood vessels. Because these forces can be transmitted to the cell nucleus, which houses the genome, mechanisms to adapt to and dissipate mechanical stress are necessary for cell survival, particularly within the nucleus itself. Importantly, defects in the mechanical properties of the nucleus can compromise cell survival during normal cellular processes, like cell migration, sometimes leading to disease. In addition, a cell's mechanical environment is defined by the tissue in which it resides, and is a key determinant of cell and tissue development. Therefore, it is an essential challenge to understand how a cell's external mechanical environment is communicated to the nucleus, where cell fate is largely determined. Moreover, the mechanical properties of the nucleus must be tuned to its tissue environment, a process that is poorly understood. This project will address these challenging questions through an interdisciplinary approach combining a genetic model organism, live-cell imaging, and biophysical tools. In addition, the supported graduate students will be trained to become the next generation of researchers and educators, who both excel at quantitative approaches and possess the biological sophistication to tackle cutting-edge biological problems.  Supported graduate students will participate in Yale's Integrated Graduate Program in Physical and Engineering Biology (IGPPEB), for which the PIs serve on the executive committee, mentor students, and teach program courses. IGPPEB provides training in communication skills, outreach activities, and teaching. Summer research opportunities will also be provided to high school students. 

 
This project will test and further develop a physical model for cell nuclear mechanics by combining novel live-cell imaging and force-spectroscopy tools capable of probing the mechanical properties of nuclei at biologically-relevant temporal, spatial and force scales, taking advantage of the genetic model system fission yeast (Schizosaccharomyces pombe). First, it will elucidate how changing the heterochromatin-euchromatin balance can alter the mechanics of the nucleus. Second, it will implement biosensors that directly measure the tension on the chromatin-inner nuclear membrane protein interface in living yeast cells in wild-type cells as well as cells with perturbed nuclear mechanics and/or chromatin states. Third, it will exploit a novel optical tweezers assay capable of applying calibrated force to nuclei in living yeast cells, thereby enabling measurements of nuclear viscoelasticity and chromatin flow in vivo. Throughout these experiments, the new information gleaned will be fed back in to a developing mathematical model of nuclear mechanics, ultimately leading to a comprehensive picture of the mechanisms that define the mechanics of nuclei. Finally, this project will test the ability of the models developed to explain nuclear blebbing, which can drive loss of nuclear integrity in transformed mammalian cells.

por.por_cntn:
The DNA in our cells is two meters long and yet it fits inside the nucleus, 100,000-times smaller. In spite of this compaction, the DNA remains accessible to the molecular machinery, necessary for gene expression. It also plays an important role in determining the mechanical properties of the nucleus. On the molecular scale, cellular DNA is organized by histone proteins that wrap 147 bp into nucleosomes, separated by 60 bp.  This is chromatin. On larger scales (105 − 106 bp), it has long been understood that loops are an essential feature of chromatin organization. The development of chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) now enables quantification of chromatin looping via a proximity ligation assay, that yields a map of the relative probability that any two genomic locations are in contact with each other. Hi-C contact maps have lead to the identification of topologically associating domains (TADs) as fundamental elements of chromatin organization. Genomic regions inside a TAD interact frequently, but have little contact with regions in neighboring TADs.

How TADs form remains uncertain.  Recently, however, the loop extrusion factor (LEF) model has emerged as the preferred candidate for how loops are created and maintained. In this model, LEFs -- identified as the Structural Maintainance of Chromosome (SMC) protein complexes, cohesin and condensin -- form the base of a loop, and initiate loop extrusion, which continues until the LEF is blocked by another LEF or a boundary element, identified in higher eukaryotes as DNA-bound CCCTC-binding factor (CTCF), or it unbinds. Thus, LEFs lead to a dynamic steady-state. However, TADs are observed in organisms where no CTCF analogue is known, and, although cohesin and condensin extrude loops on naked DNA, several measurements indicate that this activity is hindered by nucleosomes.

This project lead to the development of a new version of the LEF model, which envisions that LEF loading occurs at gene starts, which are depleted of nucleosomes, and which identifies nucleosome displacement as essential for loop extrusion. To test our model, we carried out simulations that generate theoretical chromatin loop configurations and contact maps.  These simulations reproduce key features of experimental contact maps of the mouse genome, including observed TAD boundaries, where these is no CTCF binding site.

On the experimental side, using yeast strains with compromised SMC function, which are hypothesized to reduce chromatin looping, and performing microscopy measurements to track the position versus time of individual fluorescently-labelled gene loci, this project also showed that eliminated or reduced looping leads to an increase in positional fluctuations of a fluorescently-labelled gene locus. Because single particle tracking has emerged as an important method for investigating biological dynamics of all sorts, our analysis of covariance distributions in these experiments will allow researchers to better interpret their own measurements.

Motivated by these observations, and building on our loop extrusion simulations, this project also implemented additional simulations of the configuration of chromatin, conceived as a looped polymer, which allowed us to determine theoretically the effect of looping on the positional fluctuations of a gene locus. These simulations showed that positional fluctuations of the looped chromatin polymer are increased compared to those without loops. The agreement between these simulations and our experiments represents an important independent confirmation of the direct causal connection between SMC function and looping.

In addition to loops, another level of chromatin organization is its segregation into distinct regions, namely heterochromatin, where gene expression is suppressed, and euchromatin. This segregation is driven, at least in part, by the process of liquid-liquid phase separation. Solutions of heterochromatin protein, HP1 (called Swi6 in yeast), undergo liquid-liquid phase separation in vitro and may act as a driver of euchromatin-heterochromatin separation in vivo. However, whether phase-separated chromatin domains have distinct mechanical properties, and how this could contribute to the emergent mechanical properties of the nucleus was obsure. This project examined how histone protein modifications and histone binding proteins influence nuclear mechanics. Using nuclear envelope shape reconstructions and optical tweezers-based force spectroscopy, we measured the viscoelastic properties of isolated nuclei, finding that depletion of Swi6, which suppresses heterochromatin, increases shape fluctuations and reduces nuclear stiffness. Disrupting histone H3 methylation, which also suppresses heterochromatin, has a similar effect. On the other hand, increasing histone H3 methylation, which promotes heterochromatin, reduces nuclear envelope shape fluctuations and increases nuclear stiffness. These findings show that, beyond transcriptional effects, altering the heterochromatin-euchromatin balance has mechanical consequences.

There are implications of this research for understanding and treating cancer. Specifically, the mechanical properties of the nucleus may effect cancer progression, if cancer cells have softer nuclei with enhanced shape fluctuations, that facilitate cell invasion through dense tissues. Thus, understanding the factors that contribute to nuclear mechanics has the potential to impact future cancer treatments. This project has also resulted in the training of a number of young scientists.
